reviewText: While it's totally understandable that most reviewers would have negative feelings with Barricade, and don't get me wrong many of those reasons are completely fair, I can't help but ignore all the problems and flaws and focus on the one thing Barricade succeeds at- being scary and unpredictable, two crucial elements of horror movies.  Seriously, there's nothing worse than a horror movie where you can predict every moment of the storytelling.While watching Barricade, let's be honest, practically nothing will make a bit of sense.  It's about a single father who takes his young daughter and son to a log cabin out in the woods in the middle of a snowstorm.  At first you'll think you're watching a below average horror film with predictable writing and may even consider turning it over, however I think you should keep watching because as soon as the family arrives to the house, INCREDIBLY weird things begin to happen.  I'm not sure what everyone else was thinking the entire time, but I was convinced the father was going through some kind of panic/anxiety attacks, dizzy spells and hallucinating like a madman.  This is especially apparent whenever he starts drinking and reaches for pills in the medicine cabinet.Basically the movie goes from one panic attack-like bit of storytelling directly into another without missing a single beat.  It can be overwhelming the way the movie just *pours* a neverending parade of heart-pounding horror elements at you despite hardly ever making sense, but it honestly works.  It effectively creates a feeling of anxiety for the viewers, which is why I'm not hesitating for a single moment to give the film a 4-star rating.Of course the problem here is that nobody can really *explain* what's occurring on screen.  One moment the father doesn't know what time of day it is and questions his kids when they tell him it's nighttime, the next he's locking his kids inside a room and nailing it shut because apparently there's some kind of powerful danger looming outside (or in the house) so he wants to protect his family.  To add more to the confusion, we occasionally see shadow figures standing outside in the snow.  I don't know what to make of this particular one.  The part where the daughter is kneeling down and eating macaroni and cheese on the kitchen floor is *awesome!*  You'll see why when you watch it.  THAT'S what nightmares are made of my friends!The mother/wife is deceased, and perhaps this is the one really lackluster moment of storytelling due to some *horrendous* acting when she hits her head on the side of the kitchen counter and dies.  If we ignore this one horrible moment of acting however, we're left with a pretty satisfying horror movie I believe.  Luckily the mother/wife barely appears in the movie with the exception of a few segments near the beginning and later at the end.However, the good news is that by the movies conclusion, we have logical answers!  Well one thing is logical.  I won't spoil what happens, but let's just say, the old man at the convenience store isn't nearly as innocent as he seems (not that I thought he was- hey he looked suspicious in an admittedly cliched way right from the get go).Anyway I like the frantic/nervous approach of the atmosphere and writing.  Even the kids are pretty good actors too, which is rare in television nowadays.  Usually they just throw kids on screen because they're cute enough for the part.  Not so in Barricade.  At only 75 minutes, it provides better scares than most of the acclaimed horror movies out there.  This is an example of a movie where the uncertainty of the events taking place actually adds *more* to the suspense.  You can follow this movie in that you know something really bizarre is going on- but can you guess what's going to happen at the end?  That ending is crucial.  Highly underrated.

reviewText: Cheap thrills abound. The director seemed to use every cliche as the music swelled when (you name it, cat, bird, falling object) jumped into the scene. I'm sure I've seen this plot before. Spoiler alert, it's all in his mind. Which doesn't satisfactorally explain how the children seemingly also saw some of the creeping shadows.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a good old fashion scarry movie. No bad language, no gore, no crazed slasher killers. Just good creepy, scarry goings on. Well filmed and well acted. Good Canadian scenery ( winter). It is slow paced, but builds some good suspense as it goes along. A widowed father and his two young children go to a cabin in the woods, in the winter to spend a few days. Storm comes and things get weird real fast. Enjoyable to watch and keeps you guessing what will happen next. The only down side to this movie, as far as I am concerned, is the ending. The writers could have put a better effort into explaining things. As it is, I rate it 3.5 stars.

reviewText: Haven't seen it? Don't! Gonna sit through it anyway? Okay. But don't wait for the big surprise. There isn't one!To those (like me) who dearly wish there were some kind of explanation or resolution, something we just missed, here's a take: Maybe they're insinuating that if a man were left with a woman's job, he would go clean out of his mind in short order. But because it is a silly, false premise, they were forced to keep the insinuation too-vague-to-pin-down, and THIS mess ("Barricade") is the unfortunate result.Why is the movie titled "Barricade"? Is that a clue to the mystery? If so, it is one of a casual bucketful of random "clues" that lead nowhere. What fun is a puzzle that can't be figured out because the information given is hopelessly insufficient? It's like asking X+Y=?Another problem: when Mr. Shade is shown attempting to resuscitate his wife after she slipped and fell, he suddenly stops, realizing there is a gaping wound in her chest, such that he can't continue with chest compressions. It is never explained. No more is ever revealed. No other reviewer I've read here mentions it, either.There should be some kind of special penalty given out to movies that dare end so meaninglessly. How about free ads on the sides of public transit buses in all major cities (worldwide), showing the poster with a huge fat warning: unrepentant ultra-mega-super-uber-STINKER!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Recipe for Modern Horror Movie:(1)Emotionally unstable widower/father(2)Whiny annoying  pre-teensMix well with a remote snowbound cabin, add little lighting to ensure confusion---voila, you get BARRICADE.  The film is a production of WWE Films, but mercifully no wrestlers are involved.BARRICADE is one of those thrillers that debates reality vs, insanity and fails to really resolve the debate.  The quick onslaught of the flu-like illness is also questionable.It's ultimately a parable founded in guilt and failure to act, played out in a ghostly setting.  PERCEPTION's Eric McCormack does his best in the leading role but the script's weakness leaves him sabotaged.  Trevor Morris' score is nicely eerie but the lighting is really poorly done.No gore or F-bombs so it's generally viewable.An okay rental but not a purchase unless in a bargain $5 bin.

reviewText: This movie sounds good from the description and starts out as a snow bound horror movie. But then it goes in the direction of insanity and then ends abruptly. Who knows what was real or not. I really can't recommend the movie at all due to the auduence's inability to figure out the secrets. I was hoping for a big reveal at the end but suddenly the credits started rolling.SPOILERS BELOW..................I thought the big reveal was going to be that the father murdered his entire family and went to the cabin alone. Then we find out that the wife was killed in a fall that the husband was present for. He felt so guilty that it drove him insane and killed his kids also. From the stupid ending this is probably not what happened. I would love to know what the real secrets in the movie are. There are probably clues along the way but I am not watching this movie multiple times.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I caught this on Netflix and it held my interest enough to keep me watching 'til the end.  To me, it was something of a "poor man's Stephen King (style) movie".  It had a similar weirdness to it that King adapted-for-TV movies have but without the quality of production to bring it to that level, but it's still worth watching if you're a fan of movies of this genre. One minor thing that got on my nerves has to do with the frequent coughing you hear in the movie due to the kids being sick...you hear them coughing a lot but except for one scene, you never SEE them coughing so it's very obvious the coughing sounds were dubbed in.  To summarize, this would have probably worked much better as an hour-long episode of a horror anthology series on a premium cable channel (the type of show that Showtime used to air such as Masters of Horror), but as it is it's still worth at least a rental or viewing on a streaming service.
summary: Not great but not bad - for fans of King-style TV movies
Title: N/A

reviewText: That's the question posed by this eerie, atmospheric movie set in an isolated cabin in the Canadian Rockies. In a larger philosophical sense, it's a question that almost every family faces amid the clatter of domestic dysfunction.The sharp slices of flashbacks shown in the early part of the movie suggest an answer. Then toward the end of the movie, the writers rely on flashbacks to fill in the whole of the story. That's a little lame, but this film is still worth watching for its many individual scary images. The macaroni scene is a hair-raiser.There are also some interesting extras on this DVD. We see how snow is manufactured, and are informed about the kinds of environmental restrictions that movie crews face when they are called upon to stage outdoor storms in the wilderness.  None of that old, toxic Christmas tree flocking allowed on real trees.The interior shots and the sound tend to be a little muddy. I often had to labor to see what was going on. But I found this evocation of "The Shining" to be a good choice of viewing for the coming of the cool, haunting season.
summary: Are We Locking the Monsters Out - Or Are We Locking Them IN?
Title: N/A

reviewText: The movie starts out with a husband,Eric McCormack and his wife, Jody Thomson talking about taking the kids to a cabin she and her parents used to rent for Christmas when she was a child.  Something tragic happens...then the movie jumps to Christmas, the following year.  McCormack is driving with his kids in a beautiful snowy mountainous location, heading for the cabin he and his wife had talked about.  They meet up with an older man who runs the local grocery/gas station and rents out the cabin.  He apparently has the flu but seems to be in good spirits and has set the cabin up for the kids with a tree and all the trimmings.  From there...the movie starts to spiral into some strange happenings.  All the while McCormack, who also happens to be a doctor, and his kids are coming down with the bad flu they have just been exposed to.  I feel it's worth the time to watch.  There are spooky incidents that keep you wondering what's real and what in the main characters head.
summary: Not a Bad Movie, But A Bit Confusing

reviewText: McCormack (Will of "Will & Grace" fame) did his very best to carry this film, but the burden of a confused and overextended storyline was more than he could deal with. This is not a horror tale, a ghost tale or even a supernatural tale, although the view is mislead several times into thinking it's going toward one of those directions. It's a simple thriller that is confused and meandering with an "Oh, ho hum" resolution.

reviewText: Don't read this past the first paragraph if you haven't seen the film. You know what's just as worn out as the "found footage" genre? The "we're going to make you believe one thing and it totally turns out to be something different and what that something different is...sucks"/ There's a movie called Intruders and it's the same. I'm tired of grabbing a movie because I think it's about monsters or demons, and it turns out SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT SPOILER ALERT!!!!!To not be that at all. So for no reason at all this guy starts hallucinating about ghosts or demons or whatever, and it turns out he just has a virus he caught from an old man? The kids ain't dead, they just had fevers? This movie is like getting a DVD about shark attacks and at the end, the shark turned out to be some guys mother in law she's attacking his ability to take care of his family. But on the cover of the DVD it's a picture of a shark attacking people.And can we put the word out to ask all directors to stop doing the "something walks by real fast through a window but we can't see what it is?" It's been done to death.I got this movie based off the trailer and boy am I mad. I was a sucker this time. Don't you be.
summary: I'm sick and tired of the old bait and switch
Title: N/A

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The movie opens with a scene between Eric McCormack and his "one blue dress" wife (Jody Thompson) then quickly jumps to one year later. Eric is taking his two kids Cynthia (Conner Dwelly) and Jake (Ryan Grantham) to an isolated cabin in the woods, the childhood getaway home of his now deceased wife, a cabin in the wintry woods where every horror film dwells. We are revealed details of her demise as a flashback, something they could have done better.I honestly didn't know where this was going, i.e. slasher, ghost etc. The events build slow and the next thing you know things are going on and you have no ideal what is real and what is not although the film does give clues. It turns out to be a decent mystery/horror film. I thought the title was clever as "Barricade" has a duo meaning as Eric has "barricaded" himself emotionally from his his children.When I first saw the WWE previews I did a double take as I thought I had purchased a film about a cage match.Parental Guide: No F-bombs, sex, or nudity. "S" word. Might work for a sleepover. Rated PG-13, but more of a PG-11.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For once a filmmaker wraped up the loose ends at the end of the movie and I said...Wow!!! A family gets stuck in the snow at a winter retreat..then things go downhill. 1st the caretaker of the cabin has given them all a bad cold,flu,or whatever.Then they start seeing figures out in the snow,followed by sounds in the house.Then they get completely snowed in (even covering their car)so they are trapped.When the caretaker comes to visit you figure..Yay,their gonna get rescued...wrong...he gets snatched into space by a unseen force.Who are the figures??? What snatched the caretaker into space?? What or who is in the house??? Everything is explained at the end(for once)of this riveting,not boring thriller.It kept my interest and was well done with good acting.

reviewText: I'm a little surprised by all the complaints others have about this one. Perhaps it's because this movie takes a bit of a turn that many didn't expect, myself included.If you prefer a lot of blood and gore, and a lot of violent action- this isn't for you. If you prefer everything to be explained immediately, again, not a good movie for you. This one requires some patience to see how it unwinds. The horror in this one is the unknown and the insane things that go on during their stay at the cabin. (and some 'cabin', btw...looks like a mansion to me!)It jumped around a bit, from the happenings in the cabin to flashbacks of life before his wife died to weird time warping that happens only to the main character. I found it all to be decently well done and it pulled together just fine at the end. Even without knowing the how/why of it all as it went along, I found it entertaining and wasn't completely lost, more interested in seeing what happened next.It WAS mostly explained in the end, in a somewhat-neat-but-not-all-laid-out fashion. There's just enough of a loose end to keep some suspense, but it didn't cut out with no plausible explanation. It worked for me, but seeing other reviews, it irritated others. To each their own, I suppose. I liked it.The acting was okay. Eric McCormack comes off a bit too glib at parts, and the dialogue felt a bit fake and strained at times. He does a good job in the non-verbal acting parts. Not stellar, not horrible, but good. The child actors were just okay, with the boy being far better than the girl, who I found a little too over-the-top at points.While this isn't one I'd watch again, as I know how it turns out and most of the fun in this one is the weird happenings coupled with the suspense, I though it was worth the rental.
summary: Good pyschological horror/suspense- I don't understand all the bomb ratings
Title: N/A
